title: 112_s1801
content: The "Small Business Jobs Tax Extenders Act of 2011" is the short title of the Act. It includes amendments to the 1986 Code and provides a table of contents outlining the sections of the Act. The Act aims to extend small business tax relief. The "Small Business Jobs Tax Extenders Act of 2011" extends various tax provisions for small businesses, including the exclusion of gain on small business stock, carryback of business credits, alternative minimum tax rules, reduction in recognition period for built-in gains tax, expensing limitations, bonus depreciation, long-term contract accounting rule, and deduction for start-up expenditures. Extension of deduction for health insurance in self-employment taxes. Title I of the document focuses on the extension of small business tax relief, emphasizing the importance of supporting small businesses for economic recovery. Key findings by Congress highlight the significance of small businesses in job creation and the preference for comprehensive tax reform over short-term extensions. Title I extends small business tax relief by amending the exclusion of gain on certain small business stock and extending the 5-year carryback of general business credits for eligible small businesses. These amendments apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011, and credits determined in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 103. Extension of alternative minimum tax rules for general business credits of eligible small businesses to apply to credits determined in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 104. Extension of temporary reduction in recognition period for built-in gains tax to apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 105. Extension of increased expensing limitations and treatment of certain real property as Section 179 property. Section 179(b) is amended to include 2012, 2013, and 2014 as new years for certain provisions. This includes adjustments for inflation and special rules for qualified real property. Section 179(f)(1) is amended to include 2012 as a new year. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 106. EXTENSION OF BONUS DEPRECIATION. In section 168(k), amendments are made to extend deadlines for expensing and bonus depreciation. The changes include shifting dates from 2013 to 2014 and from 2012 to 2013. Additionally, the option to accelerate the AMT credit instead of bonus depreciation is extended from 2013 to 2014. The amendment to section 168(k) adds special rules for round 3 extension property, disregarding certain limitations for taxpayers who previously elected acceleration. The amendment to section 168(k) introduces special rules for round 3 extension property, allowing taxpayers to elect not to apply certain limitations if they made specific elections in previous taxable years. The bonus depreciation amount, maximum amount, and maximum increase amount are computed and applied to eligible qualified property, specifically round 3 extension property. These amounts are calculated separately from any amounts related to eligible qualified property that is not round 2 extension property. Taxpayers who did not previously elect acceleration are subject to specific rules. The taxpayer may elect to have bonus depreciation apply to eligible qualified property for taxable years ending after December 31, 2011, if certain conditions are met. This election only applies to round 3 extension property. The text discusses round 3 extension property, which is eligible qualified property due to the extension of a special allowance under the Small Business Jobs Tax Extenders Act of 2011. Conforming amendments are also mentioned. Conforming amendments are made to various sections, changing dates from January 1, 2013 to January 1, 2014. The effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 2011, for property placed in service after that date. SEC. 107 extends the special rule for long-term contract accounting to January 1, 2013. SEC. 108 increases the deduction for start-up expenditures for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 109 extends the allowance of deduction for health insurance in computing self-employment taxes. In section 162(l), the deadline is extended to December 31, 2011. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. In section 5000A(e)(1), the affordability exception is changed from 8 percent to 5 percent.
